channel.title: scipy on Memo Tut
channel.description: Recent content in scipy on Memo Tut

item.title: [Python] Cross the walls of the left-hand and right-hand coordinate systems.
item.description: #Introduction This is a completely personal memo at that time because I needed to convert the rotation in the left-handed coordinate system (often used in computer vision and Unity) and the rotation in the right-handed coordinate system (often used in robots and physics). Since many libraries are created in the right-handed coordinate system, I have summarized how to convert at that time. 4 things that represent rotation To express rotation in the first place

item.title: [Python] [Python] Fluid simulation: Incompressible Navier-Stokes equation
item.description: ## Introduction While studying Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD), I would like to summarize the knowledge necessary for constructing a computational fluid dynamics analysis code. It seems that there are many mistakes, so please feel free to contact us if you find it. Target audience People who can use Python People who are interested in numerical calculation People who are interested in fluid mechanics Those who understand basic university physics and mathematics (simple differential equations and linear algebra?

item.title: [Python] [Python] Article that enables high-speed sparse matrix calculation
item.description: #Introduction **A sparse matrix is a matrix in which most of the elements of the matrix are 0. It is used in a wide range of fields such as numerical calculation, machine learning, and graph theory (I think). Since most of the matrix is 0, if you devise to ignore 0, you can perform matrix calculation at high speed. For example, if you use a large-scale sparse matrix (nearly 90% is 0) (1 million rows x 1 million columns) and only use non-zero parts, the calculation time will be about 1/10 and the calculation can be completed quickly.

item.title: [Python] The SEIR model was used to predict the behavior of the new coronavirus.
item.description: #1.First of all The number of new corona pneumonia (Covid-19) that occurred in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China in December 2019 is increasing in Japan. Understanding how infectious diseases such as influenza, AIDS, and SARS spread through human populations through the process of confirming the effects of health policies such as setting vaccinations and isolation of infected persons. Is also important. In the previous article, I explained the SIR model, but I will introduce the SEIR model that considers the latency of infectious diseases.

item.title: [Python] Introduction of infectious disease mathematical prediction model (SIR model)
item.description: #1. At the beginning The number of people infected with the new coronavirus (Convid-19) in Wuhan, China in December 2019 in Japan is increasing. Understanding how wrestling infectious diseases such as influenza, AIDS, and SARS spread in human populations is essential to confirm the effects of health policies such as setting vaccinations and isolating infected people. Is also important. Here, we will introduce the SIR model, which is the basis of the infectious disease mathematical prediction model, and the process of calculating this model in Python.

item.title: [Python] Statistics with python
item.description: # Total and average numpy.sum(data) # sum numpy.mean(data) # mean #Maximum, minimum, and median numpy.amax(data) numpy.amin(data) numpy.median(data) #dispersion An index that indicates how far the data is from the average \sigma^2=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{n} (x_i-\mu)^2 numpy.var(data, ddof = 0) Unbiased distribution The sample variance is a value obtained by further calculating the variance using the sample mean, but this value causes an underestimate bias. Therefore, the one without bias becomes the universal variance.

item.title: [Python] Carefully understand Poisson distribution and draw with Python
item.description: #Introduction The Poisson distribution that always appears when studying statistics, but the formula for the probability distribution did not come into my mind at all, so I tried to understand it carefully from the derivation of the probability distribution. I also draw in Python to grab the image. ##reference I have referred to the following to understand the Poisson distribution and draw the distribution. [University Mathematics] Poisson distribution (specific examples and their meanings, Poisson’s limit theorem) [Probability Statistics] Introduction to Statistics (Basic Statistics I) What is Poisson distribution?

item.title: [Python] Introduction to sparse matrix with scipy.sparse
item.description: This article is the 22nd day article of [Furukawa Laboratory Advent Calendar](https://qiita.com/advent-calendar/2019/flab). I am an OB of Furukawa Laboratory, but I was invited by a student to participate. Thank you. #Introduction This time, I would like to explain the sparse matrix and its representation format while also describing the implementation by scipy.sparse. This article is intended for people who have become accustomed to numpy to some extent, but haven’t dealt with sparse matrix-related… I just want to know a little about what it is!

item.title: [Python] How to sample from any probability density function in Python
item.description: ~~MCMC should be done! Onegacious without the tsukkomi As you know, many probability density functions are predefined in scipy, and by using them, you can easily perform sampling and plotting of probability density functions. For example, stats.norm.rvs(loc=50, scale=20, size=1000) Then you can get 1000 samples from a normal distribution with mean 50 and standard deviation 20, and x = np.linspace(0, 100, 100) px = stats.norm.pdf(x, loc=50, scale=20) plt.plot(x, px) Then we can also plot the normal distribution at $0<x<100$.

item.title: [Python] [Memorandum] Python calculation speedup (may be) module Numba related summary
item.description: I want to run a #Python program at high speed! ** “If you can calculate 10 times faster, you can make 10 times more failures” ** If you think so, everyone should think that it would be good to be able to calculate quickly. As for the title, Numba, it is a module that can accelerate the calculation on Python by using JIT (just-in-time) compiler. This article is a memorandum of past excellent articles about Numba.

item.title: [Python] Basics of trajectory generation (Scipy's optimize method for nonlinear optimal control problems)
item.description: Description of trajectory generation, trajectory planning, and how to obtain modern numerical solutions for optimal control problems. [Additional March 2017] I have released it as a python library as a development system of the contents written here. Please note that the theory implemented below is the Legendre-Gauss-Lobatto pseudospectral method, and the content on the current page is different from the Legendre-Gauss pseudospectral method. https://github.com/istellartech/OpenGoddard https://istellartech.github.io/OpenGoddard/ How to use OpenGoddard 1 How to use OpenGoddard 2 How to use OpenGoddard 3 How to use OpenGoddard 4
